xxl.cursors
Class Permutator

java.lang.Object
  |
  +--xxl.cursors.Permutator
public class Permutator
extends Object
implements Iterator

The Permutator 'returns' a permutation of a given input-array or creates a permutation of Integers from [0,..n) by lazy evaluation.
With the help of this class the caller is able to get a permutation of every kind of 1-dimensional arrays, especially integer-arrays.
Further the caller is able to choose a constructor which uses his own random number generator, e.g. with the intention to get a better permutation.

Example usage (1): 

 	Permutator permutator = new Permutator(10);
 		while(permutator.hasNext())
 			System.out.print(permutator.next() +"; ");
 		System.out.flush(); System.out.println();
This example permutates the integer numbers of the interval [0,10[.
Therefore a new integer array is created, i.e. this.array = new int[10]. In this case the Random number generator Random is used. An instance of this class is used to generate a stream of pseudorandom numbers. The class uses a 48-bit seed, which is modified using a linear congruential formula. (See Donald Knuth, The Art of Computer Programming, Volume 2, Section 3.2.1.)

If two instances of Random are created with the same seed, and the same sequence of method calls is made for each, they will generate and return identical sequences of numbers. In order to guarantee this property, particular algorithms are specified for the class Random. Java implementations must use all the algorithms shown here for the class Random, for the sake of absolute portability of Java code. However, subclasses of class Random are permitted to use other algorithms, so long as they adhere to the general contracts for all the methods.

Each call to next returns one random element of the array. After completely consuming the Permutator the result is a complete permutation of the given array.

Example usage (2): 

 	permutator = new Permutator(new int[10], new SecureRandom());
 		while(permutator.hasNext())
 			System.out.print(permutator.next() +"; ");
 		System.out.flush(); System.out.println();
A new Permutator is created with the help of a given array with the integers 0,...,9 and a SecureRandom number generator.
In this case the next method calls the method nextInt() of the class SecureRandom. This class provides a cryptographically strong pseudo-random number generator (PRNG). After consuming the whole Permutator the result is a complete permutation of the given array.

See Also:
Iterator, Random, SecureRandom

                  Random random)
Creates a new Permutator by creating an int array using the given parameter n as the array's length.
Therefore the Permutator's range is [0,n[.

Method Detail

hasNext

public boolean hasNext()
Returns true if the iteration has more elements.
(In other words, returns true if next would return an element rather than throwing an exception.)
This method is true if index < array.length.
Specified by:
hasNext in interface Iterator
Returns:
true if the Permutator has more elements.

next

public Object next()
            throws NoSuchElementException
Returns the next element in the iteration.
Each element of the array will be returned only for one time.
Each call to this method swaps two elements in the underlying array:
The position to be swapped depends on the given Random number generator and is computed with index+random.nextInt(array.length-index). The object returned by this method is the a new Integer object that is created with the integer value at the above computed position. Further the element located at this position is swapped with array[index].
Specified by:
next in interface Iterator
Throws:
NoSuchElementException - if the iteration has no more elements.

remove

public void remove()
            throws UnsupportedOperationException
This method is not supported by Permutators.
If this method is called an UnsupportedOperationException is thrown.
Specified by:
remove in interface Iterator
Throws:
UnsupportedOperationException - if the remove operation is not supported by this Permutator.
